captions.text:
The origin of copyright law takes us back
to the 1710 and Queen Anne, the Monarch who

had just overseen the Unification of England
and Scotland into then, brand-new Great Britain.

Also on her busy schedule was the Statute
of Anne: the very first copyright law. It

gave authors control over who could make copies
of their books or build on their work a limited

time.
Later a group of rebellious colonists, thought

the Statue of Anne was a good idea, and so
copy/pasted it into their own constitution

giving congress the power:
“To promote the Progress of Science and

useful Arts, by securing for limited Times
to Authors… the exclusive right to their

respective Writings”.
Basically, copyright is a contract between

authors and society: if you promise to make
more stuff, we promise not to copy it or build

on it for 28 years.
Here’s an example from the modern day: let’s

say you’re trying to be a director and you’re
looking for a project to get started.

Harry Potter is a story you’d love to remake.
But since J. K. Rowling published ‘The Sorcerer’s

Stone’ in the United States in 1998 it still
has copyright protection, so you can’t use

it.
Instead you need find something from a long

time ago, like, for example:
Star Wars: A New Hope!

George Lucas released Star Wars: A New Hope
in 1977! That’s more than 28 years ago,

So great! Get filming!
Alas, no.

While Star Wars should have lost copyright
protection in 2005 it’s actually copyrighted

until 2072!
That’s 95 years after publication, not 28!

So you can’t use it unless Lucas lets you.
Why does his copyright last for ages?

Well, as long as there has been copyright
there have been authors arguing that it’s

too short.
And perhaps, they’re right. How’s a poor

guy like George Lucas supposed turn a profit
in the mere 28 years between 1977 and 2005?

There was only the first theatrical release
of ‘A New Hope’,

And the theatrical re-released in 1978
and 1979

and 1981
and 1982

and then there was the 1982 VHS and Betamax
releases

the 1984 broadcast television release
the 1985 Laser disc release

the 1989 widescreen Laser disc release
the 1990 VHS re-release

the 1992 widescreen VHS release
the 1993 Laserdisc re-release

the 1995 VHS re-re-release
and the 1997 special edition theatrical release

Han shot first, you bastard.
and the 1997 VHS special edition release

and the 2004 DVD release
And now you, dear filmmaker, come along and

want make your own version of Star Wars:
a New Hope? For shame!

That like stealing food right out of George’s
Lucas’ mouth.

Four times Congress has agreed with authors
that the length of copyright is too short

to turn a profit and so extended it:
First in 1831 from 28 years to 42 years, then

again in 1909 to 56 years, in 1976 to the
lifetime of the author plus 50 years, and

in1998 to the lifetime of the author plus
70 years.

That’s a great deal for authors who have
already made stuff, but does it really help

society get more movies and books?
It’s hard to imagine, for example, that

Edgar Rice Burroughs started writing ‘A
Princess of Mars’ and ‘Tarzan’ in 1911

because the copyright laws had just been extended
and would not have done so otherwise.

Or that J. K. Rowling, while living on benefits
in Scotland, was busy doing the math and wouldn’t

have written Harry Potter if the copyright
protection was just for her whole life and

not an additional seven decades thereafter.
Because, exactly who needs incentives after

they’re dead? Dead is the point at which
literally no incentives in the whole universe

can motivate you to write one more screenplay.
Because you’re dead.

If you’re the kind of person who is only
motivated by plans that unravel after your

demise, you’re either amazingly awesome
or deranged.

But so what? So what if every kindergartner’s
macaroni artwork is protected by copyright

for 175 years?
Why does it matter?

Because the main beneficiaries of copyright
after death are not the authors, or society

but companies. Companies like… Disney.
Remember all the good old Disney movies?

Yeah, all of them came from works no longer
under copyright protection at the time.

The whole of the Disney Empire and all the
childhood magic that it produces only exist

because there was copyright free work for
Walt Disney – you know the guy who actually

started the whole company – to rework and
update.

But the corporate, Waltless Disney was the
big pusher of the 1998 life +70 years copyright

extension. It made sure that no one could
make more popular versions of their movies

in the same way they made a more popular version
of Alice in Wonderland.

This near-infinite control subverts the whole
purpose of copyright which is to promote the

creation of more books and movies, not to
give companies the power to stop people making

new creative works based on the efforts on
their long-dead founders.

New directors and authors need the freedom
to take what came before to remake and remix

(romeo & juliet, emma). And they should be
able to use creative material from their own

lifetime to do so, not just be limited to
the work of previous generations.

At the turn of the century, George Lucas wrought
upon civilization a new word: anticipointment.

The tremendous let-down that was the lazy,
bland, and soulless new trilogy.

George Lucas’s was completely within his
rights to make those movies into the sterile,

toy-marketing vehicles they were. He owned
Darth Vader and could tell the origin story

as he wished – and that’s the only version
you’ll ever get to see.

But, imagine for a moment, if copyright still
worked as first intended.

In 2011 the whole of the original Star Wars
trilogy – all of its artwork, its characters,

its music – would have left copyright protection
and been available to aspiring directors and

writers to build upon and make their own versions
of.

There would be a treasure trove of new Star
Wars stories for fans to enjoy.

But as long as the current copyright laws
remain as they are, no living person will

ever get to tell a Darth Vader story, or a
Harry Potter Story, or a Hobbit Story or any

other story that matters to them, that the
author or, when after their death, their company,
disagrees with.�

comments.author: johnrmcclure1

comments.text:
Copyright laws amuse me. Basically, a worthless piece of fiction is 
protected for well over 100 hundred years yet valuable patents are only 
protected for *only* 20 years. If I wrote a shitty book about travelling at 
the speed of light, the US government would protect that book for over 100 
hundred years. If I discovered how to go faster than the speed of light, 
the US government would protect me for only 20 years. Great fucking job 
with copyright laws America and other countries with similar copyright 
laws, you literally value worthless creations over valuable creations!﻿

profit, they can make their fan films/fan novels all they want. That's why 
there are so many fan films and fan-written stories on websites like 
theforce.net.﻿

comments.text:
this reasoning works very well for big companies, however if you look at 
the numbers for example about 95% of the audio industry is made of small 
businesses and large sways of self employed people who'd be badly affected.
Within the creative industries it's already hard as it is also due to the 
fact that all attention is geared towards the biggest studios anyway which 
also reinforces the public's lack of awareness.
I don't agree with incredibly long periods of time like 90 years, however 
who truly benefits from this usage of copyright are mostly companies, that 
can afford to produce and or/ get hold of many and to reach large 
populations, from Hollywood to Monsanto.
In the end everything is on a spectrum, I reckon this has more to do with a 
lack of proportionality than copyright simply being wrong and the specifics 
of how to make it fairer will vary from industry to industry; we are still 
a long way from universal sharing.l﻿

comments.author: TaydebearProductions

comments.text:
I'm anti IP, but just two points:

Copyright law predates the statute of anne by a longshot, and as a custom 
it predates the kingdom of England

And there's a reason for the "lifetime of the author plus x years" 
copyright restrictions: Self publishing authors are very unusual, 
publishing houses (you know, those evil companies mentioned in the video) 
are a pretty necessary part of the industry with or without IP. The 
argument in favour of extending copyright beyond the authors death is to 
make their work more valuable when they sell the copyright or to benefit 
their dependents. Edgar Rice Burroughs might not have decided not to write 
his books if copyright terms had remained the same, but he might have made 
less money on them.﻿
comments.author: Peter Houlihan

comments.text:
Just because someone is dead, doesn't mean they don't have children... who 
the parent would like to see receive money, from their copyrighted 
material. This is just like the "Death Tax", in the U.S.. It seems like a 
great idea, to tax the hell out of the recently dead, but just because 
they're dead, doesn't again, mean they didn't have any children, who are 
alive, who wished they would inherit their hard earned money. Sure... in 
cases like George Lucas, who is a billionaire, that might not be such an 
issue, but people on the left, in the U.S., think billionaires and small 
time millionaires, are exactly the same, thus tax them at the same rates... 
which they couldn't be more different. Just another thing, on a long list, 
that liberals think is a excellent idea, but if anyone thinks objectively 
about for more than five minutes, realizes it might not be as good, as it 
originally seemed or you're just jelous of the small time millionaires 
children, who should inherit a great deal of their parent wealth, if that 
is what they chose, before they passed.﻿

- Poorly written

---- Poorly paced plots, especially in Episode 2
---- The lack of a clear over-arching villain and a villain for the first 
two movies
- Poorly acted (by actors whom we all know can act) 
---- Mostly due to Lucas' insistence on most sets being just green screens 
with a minimal amount of actual props/sets/ 
- Poorly shot
- Over-reliance on CGI
- Over-reliance on pushing toys/merch
- Lack of a strong story 
- Lack of a strong actor for the lead role

They were poor films, especially in comparison to Episodes IV and V. Having 
said that, the films were not terrible compared to other pop corn flicks of 
the same era. They could have simply been ten time better.

comments.text:
Fanfiction is essentially illegal, since direct profit is not a factor in 
copyright infringement. If it's an actual parody you might win the case. 
Now, do the companies always send cease and desist? No. That's impossible. 
But if you spent 2 or 3 years making your own Batman movie or My Little 
Pony fangame, know that they historically can and have taken those down. 
Even if it's free.

shoddy movie which sued one of those ridiculous porn movies for infringing 
on *their* copyright.

'shrugs'

Basically if you're writing fan fiction and get a cease and desist letter 
then you should probably cease, or at least get some good lawyers and deep 
pockets. Also hope you don't get sued.

comments.author: apa aja

comments.text:
That was a dumb down historical review of copyright. The Statute of Anne 
did not give copyright to the authors, rather its owners, which were 
largely the Stationer's Company as they bought the manuscripts from the 
authors in return for royalties. The Statute of Anne was actually pushed by 
the Stationer's Company themselves and the current historical contemporary 
opinion on the matter is that copyright, as introduced in England, was 
essentially a state-granted monopoly.﻿

comments.author: Ruri Hoshino

comments.text:
Great points, but I think the biggest problem of copyright is that it 
discourages anyone from coming up with a new idea.  If you look at the 
copyright registry for any idea you have, it's very difficult to find 
something outside of copyright for you to use, for example, as the name of 
a song or even the title of a game you're making.

I remember the nightmare of looking through the registry of prefixes one 
time and everything I could possibly think of as the name of a potential 
project I was working on was listed.  It's horrible.

I honestly think that 28 years is too long, not too short of a time.  28 
years was made at a time when few people were producing content, so it 
worked for the 1700s.  In today's world, considering how time has been 
compressed based on the amount of available information and the world's 
population, the actual limitation should be around 15 years.﻿
comments.author: Global Warming Skeptic

comments.text: Dude, it's called "fan fiction".﻿
comments.author: SimonAndKeithStudios

comments.text:
You're missing something. If I create something and want money for it, I 
may not have the money to fully realize my creation (produce and distribute 
it) myself so that I can make the most profit from it. I could sell my work 
to a corporation. The longer they're capable of retaining rights, the 
greater the value I can offer them and the more they'll be willing to pay 
me. Under your suggestion, if I'm in my 60's or 70's and/or in poor health 
and I want to sell a work I created to a company to, say, help pay for 
medical expenses or have some money for my survivors, I've got less value 
to offer any buyer if my rights die with me. 

So I'm not exactly happy about the state of modern intellectual property 
law but what seems reasonable can have some nasty consequences. ﻿

comments.author: Thor Schotz (LSSJTHOR)

comments.text:
“writing the same shitty story but just putting stupid spins on it”

As if that’s not what people already do...

Anyway, do you not think it’s possible to be creative while using someone 
else’s creation? What about Disney’s movies? Were they not creative?

What about all of the stories based on old fairy tales? What about all the 
movies and TV series based on Sherlock Holmes? What about everything based 
on Shakespeare’s works? Are they not creative at all?

What about *all of the zombie apocalypse genre*? It only exists because 
Romero’s “Night of the Living Dead” was public domain by accident. Had it 
been copyrighted, we wouldn’t have “The Walking Dead”, or “Resident Evil”, 
or an absurd amount stories that belong to this genre. Do you really think 
The Walking Dead is uncreative? *Really*?

“More Star Wars” would be a good thing for the exact same reason “more 
Night of the Living Dead” *is* a good thing. Without the zombie apocalypse 
genre, *it’s a fact* we’d have much less creative stories to enjoy as we do.

A lot of derivative works are *way* more creative than “original” works 
like, say, 50 Shades of Grey.

There are some decent arguments for copyright (but not for one-century-long 
copyright), but “creativity” is the worst of all. If someone writes the 
most unoriginal and uncreative story imaginable, as long as it can be 
passed of as “the author’s own idea”, it is protected by copyright anyway. 
Same for unoriginal songs/movies/whatever. The idea that copyright somehow 
prevents people from being uncreative is ludicrous.

Of course, creative works should be protected to some extent, but not to 
the point where no one can ever create their own variations for nearly one 
fucking century. And under *no* circumstances a work should continue to be 
protected after the creator’s death.

anyone really want to drown in bootlegs?﻿

2. "Author's life plus 70 years". By author does it also mean company? Aka 
people cannot make remakes of something like Tarzan unless Disney gives

Thanks in advance.﻿
comments.author: Iron Giant

comments.text: Thanks
comments.author: Iron Giant

comments.text:
First of all, the answers to your questions will depend on what country the 
new works are published/used/sold/exploited. Assuming you are talking about 
US:
1. Copyright protection is given to derivative works (this isn't a common 
thing in other jurisdictions) that protect against works based on the 
original work. This would prevent against new versions, whereas most other 
jurisdictions would require someone to *copy* the original work, or a 
substantial part thereof, before infringement is found. Going from movie to 
book versions, or the other way around is infringement, provided you are 
substantially copying the work. However, the one big defense is fair use, 
which is where certain versions, like fan fiction, will apply. Courts will 
look at a variety of factors to determine whether something is fair use:
   the purpose and character of your use,
   the nature of the copyrighted work,
   the amount and substantiality of the portion taken, and
   the effect of the use upon the potential market.
2. When the author is a person, not a corporation, that is when copyright 
is life plus a fixed term. Don't confuse "author" with "copyright owner"; 
the author is the original owner, but they can sell the work later. If they 
sold it to a corporation, the corporation's copyright would last the 
*author's* life plus the fixed term. The life doesn't change based on who 
owns it.
If a corporation is the author, copyright protection will just be a fixed 
term (there is no "life" protection given in the legislation in such 
circumstances), so when the corporation dissolves is never an issue.
3. Copyright in the original story of Peter Pan is now in the public 
domain, so it is not protected by anyone. Anyone can copy the original 
story. However, you cannot copy Disney's productions of the story, as I 
don't think those are old enough to be in the public domain. That doesn't 
mean Disney owns the story, it means they have a more limited copyright 
protection in the way they expressed the story, so that you would have to 
basically copy exact clips from the movie to infringe. Likely the only 
reason why permission would have to have been gotten from Disney is on a 
trademark basis (which is a completely different realm). Long story short, 
using "Peter Pan" in the title may have confused people into thinking the 
live production was made by Disney (or that they were involved somehow), 
which is what the trademark protection is related to.

comments.author: Luis Miranda

comments.text:
+Torsten Adair I personally think that terms on the scale of life+50 (which 
given modern life expectancy could very easily pass the 100 year mark) are 
far too long for a world which is as fast paced and connected as the world 
is today.

When the original term of ~30 years was put into place information and 
ideas had to seep their way around the world, but you really don't need to 
accommodate for that anymore.

When you think of the pace the world moves now, and the pace that art (by 
the broadest definition) is created, it's easy to imagine that work you 
create today will have lost most of its relevance and usefulness (for the 
purpose of inspiration, remixing, etc.) in 100 years.
comments.author: Joey Sabey

comments.text:
+FraggingBard Star War Episode IV was new, in that Lucas took inspiration 
from a variety of sources, including Joseph Campbell and Leni Riefenstahl.

Science Fiction's fundamental theorem is that it uses the future to comment 
about the present.  Like many other genres, you can take a story, change 
the setting, and make it work as SF.  (For example, the SW4 work print used 
WW2 airplane battle footage as a placeholder for the attack on the Death 
Star.)

I mentioned TV Tropes, which categorizes and analyzes how stories use 
certain literary devices.

Heck, if you want to be academic about it, try these:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motif_(folkloristics) It's been going on for 
millennia.  

Yeah, there's nothing "new" about anything.  
Just new ways of mixing and matching stuff.
"It's [BLANK] meets [BLANK] by way of [BLANK]!"
or
"Hes [BLANK]. she's [BLANK].  They fight crime."
or
"A hero ventures forth from the world of common day into a region of 
supernatural wonder: fabulous forces are there encountered and a decisive 
victory is won: the hero comes back from this mysterious adventure with the 
power to bestow boons on his fellow man."
or 
"A community in a harmonious paradise is threatened by evil; normal 
institutions fail to contend with this threat; a selfless superhero emerges 
to renounce temptations and carry out the redemptive task; aided by fate, 
his decisive victory restores the community to its paradisiacal condition; 
the superhero then recedes into obscurity."

As for the corporations...  yes, BUT...
Those creators who did not do Work For Hire can sue for termination of 
copyright, which was written into the law in the 70s.  This is what 
happened with the Kirby estate (which settled with Marvel), and what is now 
hitting the fan in the music industry.  (See: Prince/Warner Brothers 
catalog, for example).

If the creator DID do work for hire...well, they should have read the 
contract.  Some companies do offer creator credit, and television does 
allow creators to get rich.  

Personally, I prefer a much shorter period of copyright.  
Life + 50 for an individual, 50 years for a corporate work.
(If you think that is not long enough, realize that patents expire after 17 
years.)
Trademarks are what corporations can use to protect their Intellectual 
Property.  You could make a movie about Superman, but you couldn't use the 
trademark.
comments.author: Torsten Adair

comments.text: Dune was a horrible movie. Deserves a remake. Lol
comments.author: Luis Miranda

comments.text:
+Torsten Adair
Star Wars isn't new you ignorant... Well, you're fairly ignorant.

But the lack of originality is part of the problem. Older works do exist 
and a lot of ideas have already been covered. For newer derivations of 
those works, like Walt Disney movies or the Star Wars movies, those older 
ideas need to be free to use.

For instance, The Matrix. It's not original, it's actually horrendously 
derivative of other works. But the other works weren't enforced, 
the Wachowski brothers got away with it, and we have an amazing film to 
see. Or again, the Star Wars films (space opera is nothing new, Dune did it 
better), or the Walt Disney movies.

As for the estate benefiting, CGP raised the good point that everyone is 
ignoring, which is publishing companies generally own more of the 
copyright, or even all rights, than the actual authors themselves. The 
estate stops benefiting, big companies benefit.

That's a problem.

So 1) you're wrong, and 2) you're wrong.
